Journal.Title: International journal of environmental research and public health
Journal.ISOAbbreviation: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Article.ArticleTitle: Changes in Air Quality and Drivers for the Heavy PM<sub>2.5</sub> Pollution on the North China Plain Pre- to Post-COVID-19.

AbstractText: Under the clean air action plans and the lockdown to constrain the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), the air quality improved significantly. However, fine particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) pollution still occurred on the North China Plain (NCP). This study analyzed the variations of PM<sub>2.5</sub>, nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub>), carbon monoxide (CO), and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) during 2017-2021 on the northern (Beijing) and southern (Henan) edges of the NCP. Furthermore, the drivers for the PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution episodes pre- to post-COVID-19 in Beijing and Henan were explored by combining air pollutant and meteorological datasets and the weighted potential source contribution function. Results showed air quality generally improved during 2017-2021, except for a slight rebound (3.6%) in NO<sub>2</sub> concentration in 2021 in Beijing. Notably, the O<sub>3</sub> concentration began to decrease significantly in 2020. The COVID-19 lockdown resulted in a sharp drop in the concentrations of PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, and CO in February of 2020, but PM<sub>2.5</sub> and CO in Beijing exhibited a delayed decrease in March. For Beijing, the PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution was driven by the initial regional transport and later secondary formation under adverse meteorology. For Henan, the PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution was driven by the primary emissions under the persistent high humidity and stable atmospheric conditions, superimposing small-scale regional transport. Low wind speed, shallow boundary layer, and high humidity are major drivers of heavy PM<sub>2.5</sub> pollution. These results provide an important reference for setting mitigation measures not only for the NCP but for the entire world.
